natural problem: Yann and Camille go to a restaurant.  If there are 10 items on the menu, and each orders one dish, how many different combinations of meals can Yann and Camille order if they refuse to order the same dish? (It does matter who orders what---Yann ordering chicken and Camille ordering fish is different from Yann ordering fish and Camille ordering chicken.)
natural solution: Yann can order 10 different dishes. After he has chosen a dish, Camille has 9 choices left for her dish, because she won't order the same dish as Yann did.
Thus there are a total of $10\cdot 9 = \boxed{90}$ different possible combinations of meals.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes menu :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "menu = 10"
shows  "card {(y, c) |y c. y \<in> {1..menu} \<and> c \<in> {1..menu} \<and> y \<noteq> c} = 90"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Yann and Camille go to a restaurant.  If there are 10 items on the menu, and each orders one dish, how many different combinations of meals can Yann and Camille order if they refuse to order the same dish? (It does matter who orders what---Yann ordering chicken and Camille ordering fish is different from Yann ordering fish and Camille ordering chicken.) The final Answer is 90
 ### Proof
 Yann can order 10 different dishes. After he has chosen a dish, Camille has 9 choices left for her dish, because she won't order the same dish as Yann did.
 Thus there are a total of $10\cdot 9 = \boxed{90}$ different possible combinations of meals.
 *)

theorem
fixes menu :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "menu = 10"
shows  "card {(y, c) |y c. y \<in> {1..menu} \<and> c \<in> {1..menu} \<and> y \<noteq> c} = 90"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: How many ways can you order two different dishes from a menu of 10? The final answer is 90.

fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 10"
shows  "n * (n - 1) = 90"

 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 10"
shows  "n * (n - 1) = 90"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 10"
shows  "fact(n) / (fact(n - 2) * fact 2) = 90"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Yann and Camille go to a restaurant.  If there are 10 items on the menu, and each orders one dish, how many different combinations of meals can Yann and Camille order if they refuse to order the same dish? (It does matter who orders what---Yann ordering chicken and Camille ordering fish is different from Yann ordering fish and Camille ordering chicken.) The final Answer is 90
 ### Proof
 Yann can order 10 different dishes. After he has chosen a dish, Camille has 9 choices left for her dish, because she won't order the same dish as Yann did.
 Thus there are a total of $10\cdot 9 = \boxed{90}$ different possible combinations of meals.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 10"
shows  "fact(n) / (fact(n - 2) * fact 2) = 90"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Calculate the value of the expression $\frac{n!}{(n-2)! * 2!}$ when $n = 10$. The final answer is $90$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes menu_items :: nat and orders :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "menu_items = 10"
and h1 : "bij orders"
and h2 : "\<forall>i j. i \<noteq> j \<longrightarrow> orders i \<noteq> orders j"
shows  "card {orders i |i. i \<in> {1, 2}} = 90"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Yann and Camille go to a restaurant.  If there are 10 items on the menu, and each orders one dish, how many different combinations of meals can Yann and Camille order if they refuse to order the same dish? (It does matter who orders what---Yann ordering chicken and Camille ordering fish is different from Yann ordering fish and Camille ordering chicken.) The final Answer is 90
 ### Proof
 Yann can order 10 different dishes. After he has chosen a dish, Camille has 9 choices left for her dish, because she won't order the same dish as Yann did.
 Thus there are a total of $10\cdot 9 = \boxed{90}$ different possible combinations of meals.
 *)

fixes menu_items :: nat and orders :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "menu_items = 10"
and h1 : "bij orders"
and h2 : "\<forall>i j. i \<noteq> j \<longrightarrow> orders i \<noteq> orders j"
shows  "card {orders i |i. i \<in> {1, 2}} = 90"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In a restaurant, there are 10 different items on the menu. Each order is a combination of two different items. Assuming all combinations are unique, how many different orders can be made? The answer is 90.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. P n = n * (n - 1)"
and h1 : "n = 10"
shows  "P n = 90"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Yann and Camille go to a restaurant.  If there are 10 items on the menu, and each orders one dish, how many different combinations of meals can Yann and Camille order if they refuse to order the same dish? (It does matter who orders what---Yann ordering chicken and Camille ordering fish is different from Yann ordering fish and Camille ordering chicken.) The final Answer is 90
 ### Proof
 Yann can order 10 different dishes. After he has chosen a dish, Camille has 9 choices left for her dish, because she won't order the same dish as Yann did.
 Thus there are a total of $10\cdot 9 = \boxed{90}$ different possible combinations of meals.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. P n = n * (n - 1)"
and h1 : "n = 10"
shows  "P n = 90"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: If $P(n) = n * (n - 1)$, what is the value of $P$ when $n = 10$? The final answer is $90$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes menu :: "'a set" and yann_orders camille_orders :: "'a \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "finite menu"
and h1 : "card menu = 10"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. yann_orders x \<longrightarrow> camille_orders x \<longrightarrow> False"
and h3 : "sum (\<lambda>x. if yann_orders x then 1 else 0) menu = 1"
and h4 : "sum (\<lambda>x. if camille_orders x then 1 else 0) menu = 1"
shows  "card { (x, y). x \<in> menu \<and> y \<in> menu \<and> x \<noteq> y } = 90"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Yann and Camille go to a restaurant.  If there are 10 items on the menu, and each orders one dish, how many different combinations of meals can Yann and Camille order if they refuse to order the same dish? (It does matter who orders what---Yann ordering chicken and Camille ordering fish is different from Yann ordering fish and Camille ordering chicken.) The final Answer is 90
 ### Proof
 Yann can order 10 different dishes. After he has chosen a dish, Camille has 9 choices left for her dish, because she won't order the same dish as Yann did.
 Thus there are a total of $10\cdot 9 = \boxed{90}$ different possible combinations of meals.
 *)

theorem
fixes menu :: "'a set" and yann_orders camille_orders :: "'a \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "finite menu"
and h1 : "card menu = 10"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. yann_orders x \<longrightarrow> camille_orders x \<longrightarrow> False"
and h3 : "sum (\<lambda>x. if yann_orders x then 1 else 0) menu = 1"
and h4 : "sum (\<lambda>x. if camille_orders x then 1 else 0) menu = 1"
shows  "card { (x, y). x \<in> menu \<and> y \<in> menu \<and> x \<noteq> y } = 90"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: There is a menu with 10 different items. Yann and Camille each order one item from the menu, but they do not order the same item. How many different pairs of items could they have ordered? The final answer is 90.
